21098: Village Elder.author: ANMist
21098: Village Elder.text_parsed:
To be honest, this is one of the cheapest green "regenerate target creature" cards that stays in play after use. If you are running a fetch land/mana ramp deck and can produce more mana through creatures than lands, this card does seem viable.

In a druid deck specifically, since early on you will be needing your mana rampers and land fetchers, having this out does make her a good blocker that is hard to kill (or to kill another of your creature for that matter) and can still be useful late game. Agreed that a land is getting sacked in the process, but having cards like groundskeeper or harrow does smoothen out her drawback. Definitely you won't be using her ability every single time and will be concentrating on building your game, but losing a land is sometimes a much better choice than losing an important creature through destroy spells/abilities or combat damage.

Now Sylvan Safekeeper is a card that does overshadow her ability for the most part, so saving creatures in combat seems to be her main asset that stands ground. IMO it does seem better to have sylvan safekeeper than her, but her ability does extend to combat and even creatures you don't control (2v2 matches for example).

In conclusion, this is surely not a great card, but helpful (and cheap) in green mana/land ramp decks.

21106: Skyshroud Elite.author: Palochka
21106: Skyshroud Elite.text_parsed:
Braid_of_Fire's Card of the Day #6

As much as I love gorillas, this is my favorite Kird Ape variant even though, like the punisher mechanic, it gives the choice to your opponent.

If you draw (as opposed to play), Game 1 this creature will generally start as a 2/3 on turn one, the equivalent of shocking yourself or grabbing a very expensive Taiga with a Kird Ape (or a Loam Lion, sure). How good is this? According to winning Zoo lists over the last five or ten years, not good enough. Perhaps I am unwise to include this but not Kird Ape in my 450 cube if that's how tournament players feel, but the satisfaction of a 2/3 on turn one in mono green, ready to block your opponent's Goblin Guide or Jackal Pup is an experience I like to have.

This card is very anti-civilization, a stance that shows green's separation from white and provides flavor-logic for the card's effect. "They have defiled nature! Our fighting spirit has increased to rid nature of this artificial, unnatural force!" is what this card is saying to me. That's a pretty strong message for green, and a good one to share in a booster pack with a new player.

The only problem with this is with these same newer players, losing to this card enough times (because newer players usually only have a deck or two) will incentivize them to use less or no non-basics, which will cause them more problems than they gain by giving this card +1/+2. Newer players won't be as quick to realize that the reason they're having difficulty casting spells is because of their weaker mana base and they will think they are "correct" to make this sacrifice for the benefit of keeping the Elite down. It's likely the reason it hasn't been reprinted and won't be.

I only wish this were common for my 12-land pauper stompy.

21124: Wind Drake.author: Wulfsten
21124: Wind Drake.text_parsed: This is what balance looks like, in my opinion. Back in the day, everyone understood that a basic 2/2 cost 2 mana, a basic 2/2 flying cost 3 mana, etc. And if it was any better, it needed a drawback or it needed to cost more. Nowadays there's no concept of an equation of cost to benefit. You might see a card like this reprinted these days in the same set as a 4/3 flying for 4 mana with flying, first strike, and the ability to draw a card every time a creature dies. Ridiculous.
21124: Wind Drake.text_posted: This is what balance looks like, in my opinion. 21125: Manta Riders.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
21125: Manta Riders.text_parsed:
This is a very flavourful creature! Manta rays actually do leap right out of the water occasionally, so I guess the merfolk are getting in on that by hitching a ride!

Oddly, though, this merfolk breaks rank with most Tempest flavour. Rathi merfolk are called rootw.ater merfolk, and they have a pretty definitive style (creepy as hell, actually - only Shadowmoor's merfolk come close). Four of the mer in Tempest are rootw.ater merfolk, and then we have this one standout - with their bright colours and flowing hair, they look more Vodalian than Rootw.ater!

21126: Mana Leak.author: Equinox523
21126: Mana Leak.text_parsed: One of the best soft counters ever printed. This was a great alternative to Counterspell in decks that had a varied manabase, and also effective in the early game to buy some time. This, along with Power Sink, kept players from tapping out to cast big spells or creatures, and expecting it, many people hesitated before casting spells while their opponent had two islands untapped. THis is without a doubt a great spell in a blue mage's arsenal, and made even more enticing as a potential core set reprint now that Cancel has replaced Counterspell.

21137: Curfew.author: Internet_decks_lame
21137: Curfew.text_parsed:
Great 1 mana response against any Reanimator, Progenitus, or single creature combo deck. Putting the card back into the players hand vs putting it into his graveyard, which forces a whole new cycle of discard then animate.

Spell does not target at all... allowing to go through any protections and not being vulnerable to deflection tricks from great cards like swerve.

Also, a great respone for protecting a vital creature from opponent's removal spell. Not to mention, potentially sending one of their creatures back during the save... 5/5

Combo up with stingscourger, Man-o'-War , and aether membrane for maximum game delay.

21145: Plains.author: Palochka
21145: Plains.text_parsed:
Braid_of_Fire's Card of the Day #10

I just random card'ed over here from Goblin War Buggy and couldn't help but comment. I've made great efforts to explore all the art of Magic's lands, but I've never had the fortune of coming across this one. As a mountain man through and through, I find it hard to resist other basic lands that look like or feature dramatic peaks, and this land delights. Too bad it's from one of the most obnoxious lands to collect from; I think I'd have an easier time filling a cube with 40 of Rebecca Guay's Plains featuring the Great Wall.

I really do like it when I feel as though I could explore the place being depicted on a card. Many other plains from this era don't resonate with me like this one does, presenting a few bushels of wheat at best. More modern Plains cards are so clearly digital that it ruins the mystique, a problem unique to basic lands. They should reprint this in the next core set.

21146: Thalakos Lowlands.author: Nathreet
21146: Thalakos Lowlands.text_parsed: Underrated budget dual. Don't underestimate any land that comes in untapped. What you do is try to use {1} as much as possible and {U}/{W} only when necessary. Still better than color screw. And since I usually am only forced to use it for colored 0 or 1 times, it's better or at least par with the guildgates. I have no idea why azorius guildgate is 3 stars and this is 2.5. Rarely do you need to use this land for colored twice. What I do is run 3 adarkar wastes and 2 thalakos lowlands. That way I limit the chance of drawing duplicates and have other lands to tap for colored as much as possible, but still get 5 color fixing lands. Budget duals aren't mutually exclusive; run them all.

21148: Subversion.author: tavaritz
21148: Subversion.text_parsed:
Reprint sets up to Starter 2000 used original expansion symbols: Chronicles, Anthologies, Battle Royale & Starter 2000. From Beatdown they started to have new expansion symbols in reprint sets.

Reprint sets witch are sold in premade packages of cards use the commonality marking of the origin set even though the commonality doesn't mean anything when you get the same cards in every packet.

Basic sets didn't have symbols up to the the fifth edition. 6th edition forward they had their own symbol.

21149: Pestilence.text_posted: Okay so I haven't played in a long time, but I remember that I used to use this card wrong.  So pretend you and I are playing.  Pretend it is my turn.  I am about to use my pestilence.  Since I don't have to tap it, Can I pay more than one black mana for the damage?  How does that work?

21149: Pestilence.author: TheMurderousKitten
21149: Pestilence.text_parsed:
@littlelorelai:
Yes, you can pay more than one to use Pestilence's ability. You can do it as many times as you have mana. Technically, each time you tap and use it is a separate event on the stack and should be done one by one, but I don't know anybody who really worries about it if you just say you're tapping for 5 damage or whatever. If they have something they want to do in response to the first activation, they can just say so and you can wait to activate the remaining 4 or whatever amount you are planning to use.
Also, your post mentions it is your turn when you do this. Although you can use Pestilence on your turn, I generally prefer to wait until my opponent's turn, just to discourage him from playing any creatures or attacking me.

21149: Pestilence.author: whiteshadw

Shroud only protects creatures from spells or abilities that have 'target' in their wording. Since this says 'each creature' and not 'any number of target creatures' shroud does nothing.
21149: Pestilence.text_posted:
@zombiefanboy_uk

21153: Exhume.author: Kale_Eledar
21153: Exhume.text_parsed:
My friends, this was a common because in Urza's Saga, most large creatures had second turn drawbacks, such as echo, or having to sacrifice an enchantment during your upkeep, or not untapping. I thinkChild of Gaea was one of the few. In today's environment, though, this card is unbelievably sick. Ridiculous cards with no drawbacks except cost didn't really exist back then. If you had told me about any of the Eldrazi gods back when Urza's was out, I would have been aghast. However, the main reason this is common is because it was printed in Urza's "What Were We Thinking" Saga, a set that has some of the most broken cards of all time, like Yawgmoth's Will, Tolarian Academy, Smokestack, Back to Basics, and Gaea's Cradle.

But yeah. This is a reanimator staple.

21168: Cackling Fiend.author: DarthParallax
21168: Cackling Fiend.text_parsed:
even if you have 2 opponents, this isn't good enough to me.

even if you're playing with an ally in 2-HG, this doesn't YET seem good enough to me.

but you know, discarding a card is discarding a card. not the best but far from the worst thing to be doing. I would absolutely try sliding this in to a meant-for-5-players deck.

Pretty sure 5 is just the best number of people to play Magic. More than than, and you have to split up into duels. (I don't exactly like Draft very much. I like mind games, but I prefer the mind games of everyone playing the same duel to Drafting mind games.)

Domain is a good mechanic when you have all 5 colors, most multiplayer cards are Good-Very Fine at 5 players. 3 isn't *quite* enough and if you can get 4 players you really want to start looking for a 5th, unless you're two couples way too nerdy to play bridge >.< 4-colored Commander decks might as well be 5 and have done with it.

With a 20-point life total, 3 is seen as the 'acceptable' rate of damage for a win-con card, and 4 or 5 look downright AWESOME. (2 power creatures and 2 damage spells are fine to start out with, but they're just never going to be your favorites unless they do something extra and stupid like draw a zillion cards.)

4 or 5 is the number you ALWAYS want to see in Magic, for just about everything. Even Planeswalker Mana Costs ^_^

21170: Cinder Marsh.author: leomistico
21170: Cinder Marsh.text_parsed:
For whoever is wondering why they didn't print the enemy version of this land in Kamigawa: because they thought at that time that enemy colours should have been more difficult to play than ally colours. In fact there wasn't a single cycle of enemy colour land, with the exception of Apocalypse lands. You can see it clearly with Tempest lands: they printed something like Caldera Lake, that is much worse than IceAge painlands. It was like they put every possible drawback in these lands... And actually it was only from recent times that they go for balancing every colour pairs in lands... This fact always ***ed me, because I always liked enemy colour pairs, like and , more that ally colour pairs! Come on! Please complete this cycle, the refugee, the manland, and the others!

As for this cycle, I find those lands quite playable, at least for budget. They come into play untapped, you can use them already, if you topdeck them they aren't a problem. Just, don't play 2 or 3 playset in the same deck, because they could become annoying if you need to add coloured mana every turn. They aren't an automatic 4x, but I think that it's a nice thing: you have to actually think when you build your deck. I think that if R&D wants to limit 3+ colour deck, they have to print this (whole) cycle, M10/Innistrad land and/or painlands, because none of them are automatically 4x and aren't easy to play in a 3colour deck.

3.5/5
21170: Cinder Marsh.text_posted:
For whoever is wondering why they didn't print the enemy version of this land in Kamigawa: because they thought at that time that enemy colours should have been more difficult to play than ally colours. In fact there wasn't a single cycle of enemy colour land, with the exception of Apocalypse lands. You can see it clearly with Tempest lands: they printed something like [autocard]Caldera Lake[/autocard], that is much worse than IceAge painlands. It was like they put every possible drawback in these lands... And actually it was only from recent times that they go for balancing every colour pairs in lands... This fact always pissed me, because I always liked enemy colour pairs, like [U][R] and [W][B], more that ally colour pairs! Come on! Please complete this cycle, the refugee, the manland, and the others! 

As for this cycle, I find those lands quite playable, at least for budget. They come into play untapped, you can use them already, if you topdeck them they aren't a problem. Just, don't play 2 or 3 playset in the same deck, because they could become annoying if you need to add coloured mana every turn. They aren't an automatic 4x, but I think that it's a nice thing: you have to actually think when you build your deck. I think that if R&D wants to limit 3+ colour deck, they have to print this (whole) cycle, M10/Innistrad land and/or painlands, because none of them are automatically 4x and aren't easy to play in a 3colour deck.

3.5/5

21175: Fertile Ground.author: majinara
21175: Fertile Ground.text_parsed: Cards that fetch lands from your library and put them into play are better most of the time. They increase your chance of drawing non-lands in the late game, and are not as easily removed as auras. In decks meant to be played in teams (2vs2, 2HG or something like that), this becomes much better, since you can play it on your teammates lands in case he gets manascrewed.

21175: Fertile Ground.author: blurrymadness
21175: Fertile Ground.text_parsed:
Cards that fetch lands don't ramp you that turn and lands in your deck that are various colors may draw you an unusable hand (I.E. no green. This has happened to me several times with as few as 4 non-forests in a deck.)

If you're merely splashing other colors and wish to ramp AND color fix, these work. Also, cards like utopia sprawl are effectively free the turn you play them. Most ramp cards cause the lands to be tapped or cost more than they give; further slowing you. This for example costs essentially one mana if you have two mana to cast it on an untapped land.

You also can't landwalk an enchantment. PLUS this ignores all of the combo potential of untapping said land for multiple mana.


So there are a fair few reasons why these work in place of fetch-land cards. Highly depends on the deck. (See enchantresses)

21182: Argothian Elder.author: Snafinturtle
21182: Argothian Elder.text_parsed:
All in all, depending on how you want to destroy your opponent, any 2mana land from the ravnica block works in combination with Wirewood Lodge. It's not necessary to run Gaea's Cradle, although it is more effective and doesn't reduce your land advantage.

Generally you'll get something useful (x-wise) off with any combination, such as:

Green/White: Decree of Justice, infinite angels
Green/Black: Drain life, take a guess
Green/Red: Banefine/Comet Storm/Pyromatics, damage
Green/Blue: Stroke of Genius, Draw your opponent out

Freed from the Real is indeed a powerful card, but it forces you to run blue, not that that generally puts you at a disadvantage, but the other colors have more X bombs to use with the infinite mana.

Combo's mentioned above can be countered, redirected, ... but more importantly, they depend on more cards if playing in multiplayer. I suggest following combo: Freed from the Real + Psionic Gift and 2 Islands is enough to destroy everyone.

I used it a few times (supported with Leyline of Anticipation, Leyline of Lifeforce and a few Privileged Position), by the time my opponent realized what was coming, it was already too late. Especially when you keep him busy with big green creatures.
The times after the first party, my opponents knew about the combo and saved spells to break it, but were smashed by the big creatures. I had my fun playing with this little creature and seeing the look in the eyes of my opponents once they realized what they were up against. Ha!

21188: Elvish Lyrist.author: The_Murderauder
21188: Elvish Lyrist.text_parsed:
Good card. But the more interesting thing about this card is that it was the only card besides Pestilence and Flood to have its rarity changed from its most recent printing when it was reprinted in the Battle Royale box set. Unlike those, though, this didn't have its expansion symbol updated to reflect its new rarity (well, Flood didn't need to anyway, because its expansion symbol was already appropriate for both rarities).

This begs the question: why? What was going on here? Perhaps we'll never know.

Perhaps an even better question: why did they bother swapping rarities at all, since this was a box set, and all the cards had a fixed rate of appearance anyway?
21188: Elvish Lyrist.text_posted:

This begs the question: why? What was going on here? Perhaps we'll never know.

Perhaps an even better question: why did they bother swapping rarities at all, since this was a [i]box set[/i], and all the cards had a fixed rate of appearance anyway?

21188: Elvish Lyrist.author: DarthParallax
21188: Elvish Lyrist.text_parsed:
The Murderauder: actually, now that we've seen a great number of Box Sets get printed, it's almost always a good thing to have the Expansion symbol colored:


Yes, the EXACT reprintings in the Box Sets are all about equally rare, but when a Rare card gets reprinted it's just different than a Common card getting reprinted.

Some striking examples I can think of that seem to not really make sense is Demonic Tutor not being a Rare in the Duel Deck, and Urza's Rage is not the best card to update as a Mythic. (although I think Mythic is kind of the best rarity for it, it just doesn't look good next to many Mythics today. It compares fine to Shards of Alara block.)

Demonic Tutor remained uncommon because for Duel Decks, they have a set number of rares they were allowed to use. Really, keeping such cards at Uncommon means they are 'stuffing the decks' with more 'basically as good as rares' than they strictly are promising. "Great Uncommons and Commons" are like "Bonus Rares" in these situations. (Kinda like Daze in Duel Decks Jace v. Chandra and Swords to Plowshares in Duel Decks Elspeth vs. Tezzeret).

Even though every single card in the box sets should be just as valued as each other, they aren't, because they're different power levels, and though the box set adds the same number of cards to the market for each, the card's original rarity holds a lot of sway over it's supply and demand, USUALLY. So reprinting cards in Box Sets and retaining their rarity symbols is actually a good way of trying to let people know that some of the cards in the Box are more valuable than others. The only sad thing is that cards like Counterspell and Demonic Tutor and a scary percent of Premium Deck Series Graveborn could have all gotten Rare Symbols to help people realize that....umm....Good Cards are Way Good. :D

21196: Dirtcowl Wurm.author: The_Murderauder
21196: Dirtcowl Wurm.text_parsed:
An interesting thing to note about the Battle Royale box set reprints is that they gave us colored expansion symbols for cards that previously didn't have them.

This was a rare in Tempest, but at the time Tempest was printed, they didn't print the expansion symbols in different colors to differentiate rarities. Here, we still have the Tempest expansion symbol, but it's colored gold. The same was true of other sets in the block, like Stronghold.

Other examples: Wildfire Emissary, Living Death, Spike Feeder, as well as the dual land cycle that included Cinder Marsh and Mogg Hollows. (And more).

Interestingly, they did not give expansion symbols to cards that currently had no expansion symbol at all, like Blinking Spirit or Swords to Plowshares.

Perhaps even more interesting; they did not update the expansion symbol for Flood to reflect its true rarity, and to my knowledge, there is no printed card with anything other than a black expansion symbol from The Dark.

This is meant to provide a little early-to-mid game beef in a deck that includes Green but is not predominantly Green. In such a context, this card can be decent.

Strangely, I find that if I start sliding Green into a deck to provide 'Green support', I tend to convert the deck into a Green deck that is supported by the other color(s). Green's mana ramp is pretty powerful, but it usually calls for {G} production at the earliest opportunity, rather than secondarily.
